cmCourseInfo.description: This is an interdisciplinary course examining the development of the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender and Queer (LGBTQ) movement and its interaction with the state in the US and Canada. (Given by the Department of Political Science and the Sexual Diversity Studies Program)
cmCourseInfo.title: Sexual Diversity Politics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SDS255H1/SDS256H1/UNI255H1/UNI256H1/one full course on the politics of 20th century Europe, U.S., or Canada/one full course on gender or sexuality/permission of the instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Delivery Method: IN PERSON

 

 

 

Delivery Instructions

Former delivery method: in person

New delivery method: online synchronous

  • It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: What role have sex and sexuality played in the formation of the modern nation state? How has the state regulated sex? This course explores these questions with a theoretical focus on biopolitics. We will proceed in two parts. First, we engage Foucault’s History of Sexuality and its reception by postcolonial theorists, focusing on questions of state building. The second part of the course shifts examination from state formation to contemporary forms of sexual regulation by the state. This includes maintenance of the public/private divide, citizenship law and nationalism, administrative violence and the prison industrial complex, and neoliberalism and BDSM. By the end of the course, students are able to apply core theoretical concepts and identify forms of contemporary sexual regulation in a variety of Western and non-Western contexts. (Given by the Department of Political Science and the Mark S Bonham Centre for Sexual Diversity Studies.)
cmCourseInfo.title: Sex and the State
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A combined minimum of 1.0 credit from POL and/or SDS courses
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: POL378H1 (Topics in Comparative Politics II: Sex and the State), offered in Fall 2017 and Fall 2018; SDS375H1 (Special Topics in Sexual Diversity Studies A: Sex and the State), offered in Fall 2017 and Fall 2018

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Delivery Method: ONLINE SYNCHRONOUS

 

Delivery Instructions
  • This is an online course combining asynchronous online lecture with synchronous online discussion and activities. The course engages topics that can be considered sensitive and controversial. Ideally, students will be able to commit to 1-2 hours of scheduled synchronous activity per week, but accommodations will be made for students whose remote learning environment prohibits discussion of sensitive topics or who are unable to “attend” virtually because of time zone differences.
  • All course material is free and available online. Readings, assignments, rubrics, and syllabus are posted online via Quercus.
  • Students need a computer with the internet and a microphone (camera is optional but recommended) and the ability to use Quercus and Zoom.
